page.title: 10BENINGTON SCHOOL (1)
page.content: Education in Benington is first record- ed in the Will Of Henry Dixon dated 1651 in which provision was made for placing poor boys into apprenticeships to handicraft trades. We next hear of a Sunday School being held in the Chancel of the Church and a "Dame School or two" being held in the cottages. In 1836 moves were made for the establishment of a permanent school in Benington and it was stated that the school would receive "40 little boys and 50 girls in one room."The Fees were to be one penny per week.The total cost of the building was 158 pounds. The school was completed in 1843. In 1873 a new Nation School replaced the former building on a new site. This was for the instruction of the labour- ing poor who lived within one mile of the village. (Cont.)
